Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story:
I stared at my computer screen, headset pressing into my ears, as another call connected. “Good afternoon, this is Alex from BrightNet Services. How can I help you today?” The man on the other end immediately launched into a barrage of technical questions about our new internet package—questions my script only half-covered. I tried to sound confident, flipping through the FAQ, but my answers felt hollow. I could sense his frustration growing, and I felt the pressure to keep him interested, to not lose another potential sale.

Just then, my phone buzzed with a message from Mary, a parishioner. “Hi, Alex. I was wondering if we could talk sometime soon? I’ve been struggling and could use some guidance.” My heart twisted. As a priest, I was supposed to be present, compassionate, available. But right now, I was supposed to be persuasive, knowledgeable, and efficient. I glanced at the clock, torn between the demands of my job and the needs of my congregation. My mind raced, caught between the script in front of me and the silent plea in Mary’s message, unsure which role I could afford to let down.
